ranked_diseases.explanation: Perfect match with all major features: pancytopenia, chromosomal breakage with crosslinking agents (diagnostic hallmark), radial ray defects (absent radius/thumb), short stature, and cafe-au-lait spots. FANCA is the most common complementation group.
Matches all hematologic features and chromosomal instability, but FANCC typically has milder skeletal abnormalities. However, severe radial ray defects can occur in some cases.
Consistent with pancytopenia and chromosomal breakage, but FANCD2 patients often have less severe skeletal malformations. The bilateral radial ray defects make this less likely.

TAR syndrome features bilateral absent radii but characteristically preserves thumbs, opposite to this patient. Also lacks chromosomal instability and typically has isolated thrombocytopenia rather than pancytopenia.
Can present with anemia, short stature, and thumb abnormalities, but typically features pure red cell aplasia rather than pancytopenia. Lacks chromosomal instability and radius defects are uncommon.
Features upper limb malformations including radial ray defects, but lacks hematologic abnormalities, chromosomal instability, and skin findings. Primarily a cardiac-limb syndrome.
